title: Citing linguistic data: The Troms√∏ Recommendations
abstract: An introduction to The Troms√∏ Recommendations For Citation of Research Data in Linguistics, which help language researchers properly cite language data & give credit to everyone who contributed. Includes an intro citation formats & how to improve #lingdata citation generally.

title: What's in a name?
abstract: Do people judge using a proper noun?  Of course, sometimes, yes, they do.  This is because of the cognitive impact experienced in colossal numbers, either positive or negative.  Consequently, there are name changers, naming consultancies etc.

title: Modelagem de constru√ß√µes de Pret√©rito Imperfeito
abstract: Este trabalho objetiva apresentar a modelagem de constru√ß√µes de Pret√©rito Imperfeito em Portugu√™s Brasileiro e em Espanhol, a fim de contribuir com o desenvolvimento de um sistema de tradu√ß√£o por m√°quina que utiliza um recurso computacional l√©xico-construcional.

title: The Linguistic Landscape of Bilingual Picturebooks
abstract: In this presentation I analyse a sample of MƒÅori-English bilingual picturebooks, and suggest that the Linguistic Landscape of bilingual picturebooks are powerful tools for changing language hierarchies and for supporting the revitalisation of indigenous languages.

title: Tweets on Nominalization
abstract: Quando Bach comp√¥s uma m√∫sica, a 'composi√ß√£o' √© a m√∫sica. Quando o governo documenta um cidad√£o, a 'documenta√ß√£o' n√£o √© o cidad√£o, mas os documentos. Os nomes em -√ß√£o denotam entidades criadas por dois meios: no primeiro caso, olhando para fora do nome; no segundo, para dentro.

title: Value judgments associated with allophones of alveolar tap and trill
abstract: Migration and geography in Costa Rica have produced a complex distribution of /…æ/ and /r/ allophones. Social changes, academic figures and mass media have led to stigmatization of some variants. This work is study of value judgments associated with the different variants.

title: Nostalgia, pol√≠tica e discurso
abstract: At√© que ponto a percep√ß√£o do passado molda e estrutura a forma de perceber o mundo e, principalmente, o pol√≠tico? O trabalho visa entender as condi√ß√µes de produ√ß√£o da rede e sua rela√ß√£o com a mem√≥ria discursiva presente em enunciados de redes sociais.

title: Exploring Loanword Networks
abstract: Word borrowing is often investigated using frequency-based measures, such as types and tokens in a corpus. We introduce an alternative approach to studying loanwords, which involves building collocation networks, based on sets of borrowings that co-occur within the same text.

title: No queremos cualquier verdad
abstract: ¬øCu√°l es el valor de ‚Äúcualquier‚Äù en ‚ÄúNo queremos cualquier verdad"? Defendemos que es un universal que, al ser negado, nos invita a una lectura existencial en la que el agente tiene la libertad de elegir de todas las opciones posibles aquella se ajusta mejor a su voluntad.

title: Tempering and Aligning Advice-Giving Through Memes
abstract: Capturing peer communication in a health corpus, I show one use of memes is advice giving. Posts endorse a reader‚Äôs future action, framed as disaffiliation to shame reader choices or affiliation to encourage them. These signal positioning in vernacular online conversation.

title: Place identity & co-occurrence in Northern Maine
abstract: I examine the relationship b/w place identity and the co-occurrence of was leveling and demonstrative them in Maine English. Male-presenting speakers w/ high local affiliation combine nonstandard variants more, likely since place ideologies are tied to gender, class and ethnicity

title: The demise of impersonal constructions
abstract: So-called impersonal verbs are predicates which occur without a nominative argument. This presentation undertakes the quantitative and qualitative study of the competition between the impersonal verb hunger and the adjectival construction be hungry in Early Modern English.

title: Pros√≥dia e entoa√ß√£o: as quest√µes disjuntivas do PB
abstract: As interrogativas disjuntivas s√£o aquelas que oferecem as op√ß√µes de resposta em sua composi√ß√£o: "quer uva ou ma√ß√£?". Buscando responder quais s√£o e como se manifestam as marcas dialetais do PB, investigamos a entoa√ß√£o desse subtipo fr√°sico em grava√ß√µes de 25 capitais brasileiras.

title: Determinatives are far from pronouns in English
abstract: Using 232 morphological, syntactic, semantic & phonological features and the DISCO test, I show for the first time that determinatives & pronouns are statistically significantly different categories (p<0.001). This holds for the subsets of features (morph, syn, & sem).

title: Emoji based reactions to the Said Construction
abstract: Said used in place of a determiner seems to carry a unique social meaning. I present results of a study where participants were more likely to react to said containing sentences with üòÇ. Identical sentences with a standard det got a üëç reaction

title: #AboriginalEnglish: BE LIKE, stability and change
abstract: Our synchronic/diachronic dataset offers broad view of #AboriginalEnglish quotation. Findings based on 48 speakers b. 1907-2005 allow tackling ‚Äòactuation problem‚Äô: why changes occur in some varieties, not others.

title: Perception of American English pure vowels
abstract: We study the perception of American-English (AE) vowels by Persian and Persian/Azeri (Turkic) learners. We test their perceptual assimiltion and compare the mapping of AE vowel space by L1 listeners and our learners, using a synthesized vowel space varying formants and duration.

title: Interactionally situating the power scream
abstract: Language emerges from bodies, but some sounds are treated by interlocutors as particularly ‚Äòbodily motivated‚Äô. This study uses conversation analysis to study how a corpus of grunts (365) blur the lines between ‚Äòphysiological byproduct‚Äô & ‚Äòsocial display‚Äô #nonlexicals #emca

title: Why are we *quick* to point out, but not *fast*?
abstract: We are *quick*, but not *fast*, to point out, because of 'quick's  inceptive readings. These and a volitional agent are typical of the  construction, as opposed to the competing '-ly' forms, but also  alternative ways of combining with an infinitival ('Pasta is fast to prepare').

title: What the Italian subjunctive "actually" means
abstract: Is the Italian subjunctive used to convey doubt, desire, non-assertion? Is it disappearing from the language? Do southern Italians use it less/differently than northern Italians? Quantitative and statistical examination of spontaneous speech data says no

title: Empirical methods for describing TAM
abstract: I discuss different types of evidence for TAM descriptions offered by empirical methods, such as corpus work, storyboards and translation-based questionnaires, by focusing on irrealis mood and perfect aspect in Nafsan (Vanuatu, Oceanic).

title: Positional Preference of Emotion Phrase in Hindi
abstract: Taking permutations of phrases denoting Stimulus, Response & associated Emotion in an event involving an emotional component, the paper finds emotion-specific preference of phrase ordering in Hindi and classifies Ekman‚Äôs six basic emotions in Hindi based on these characteristics

title: We don‚Äôt agree (only) upwards
abstract: Is agreement upward or downward? In our tweets we argue that Bjorkman & Zeijlstra‚Äôs (2019) proposal that Agree is upward checking and downward valuation is empirically not adequate. Data from Bantu languages, German, and Nez Perce suggest that upward valuation is not exceptional.

title: The F2 Robot Interaction System
abstract: Our multi-layered text analysis system allows the robot F2 to interpret participants of the situation as protagonists or antagonists, and construct a list of possible speech and gesture reactions to be selected according to the simulated mood of the robot.

title: Acquisition of syntactic negation & NC
abstract: This study focuses on investigating the mismatch in the use of negative elements in standard English between child and adults‚Äô speech. It also shows that NC provides essential support for children to acquire the formal features of negation.

title: Kazym Khanty -en: 2SG possessive‚Äî>proprial article
abstract: This talk argues that the Kazym Khanty exponent -en stands for four distinct morphemes: 2SG possessive, salient article, anaphoric article, proprial article. The four differ w. r. t. competition with other possessives, agreement in number with the addressee and other features.

title: Cracking stereotypes the ling of discourse markers
abstract: The use of discourse markers in oral speech is often stereotyped in English. Yet DMs are anything but absurd words. My thread will describe some linguistic traits of DMs across languages, with a focus on Berber, and show how central they are to human grammar & communication.

title: Lexical classification of Tup√≠-Guaran√≠ languages
abstract: With two methods employed in genetic analyses -- character and distance-based -- we classify Tup√≠an languages based on lexical items from the Tup√≠an Lexical Database (TuLeD). Results agree with previous classifications and support some linguistic and ethnographic conjectures.

title: The way Spanish and Basque think about causality
abstract: This psycholinguistic study explores the role of intention in the way Spanish and Basque speakers think and talk about causal events. Results show that both speakers use similar linguistic structures to encode causality but conceptualise it significantly differently.

title: Social influence on negation in Early Modern Dutch
abstract: This presentation offers a description of the different grammars that have arisen under the influence of both bottom-up and top-down change in negation in 17th century Dutch, from consistent single negation to consistent negative concord, depending on social class and region.

title: How to clip words in English
abstract: How do speakers of English make a short word out of a longer one? We put together a collection of 2400 English clippings and analyzed it with multivariate statistics. We detected patterns and regularities that reflect functional pressures that act on the speaker and the hearer.

title: The QUD in quantity judgments
abstract: Questions like ‚ÄúWho has more jewelry?‚Äù might seem straightforward to answer, by counting the pieces, but it has been shown that the answer changes with how and when the question is asked. I argue that the answers are based on what the Question Under Discussion is assumed to be.

title: Intensifiers across social media
abstract: Much linguistics, wow! Intensifiers like 'very', 'so' are typical for informal, spoken language, but also occur in social media. @tschfflr shows individual speaker differences in choice of intensifiers in German blogs and tweets by the same authors.

title: Gaze-selection & syntax in multiperson interaction
abstract: I investigate how gaze relates to the grammatical features of turn-construction in collaborative turns. Gaze-selected speakers can provide syntactically more complex (re)completions, self-selected speakers simpler ones: do gaze-selected speakers display more entitlement to speak?

title: Variation in framing of real-world events
abstract: "Riots" or "demonstrations"? "Terrorism" or "rebellion"? The same event can be conceptualized and framed in many ways using language. We present analysis methods, #FrameNet lexicons and #NLP tools for üá≥üá±üá¨üáßüáÆüáπ to investigate how this works.

title: Because-X and because-ellipsis: A comparison
abstract: We argue that because-X (‚ÄòI can‚Äôt come because school‚Äô) is a (non-elliptical) fragment based on corpus, acceptability, and fill-in-the-blank data. This explains the acceptability of the varied categories of complement as well as the low acceptability of finite verbs and DPs.

title: who gives what to whom, and how do we know
abstract: if you can‚Äôt distinguish between who‚Äôs the giver and who‚Äôs the recipient, because case marking is gone ‚Äì does sticking a preposition on one of them help, or does fixing word order do the trick? looking at the history of giving verbs in English will tell

title: O efeito de chunking na aprendizagem do PBL2
abstract: Investiga√ß√µes conduzidas pela perspectiva Funcional-Cognitiva revelam que o processo cognitivo chunking tem papel fundamental para que sequ√™ncias da L2 sejam acessadas e armazenadas como blocos de forma-sentido, necess√°rios √† emerg√™ncia de uma forte rede construcional na mente.

title: E quando professor de ingl√™s ensina PLE?
abstract: Analisamos representa√ß√µes discursivas de professores de l√≠ngua inglesa, ao enunciarem sobre o ensino-aprendizagem de Portugu√™s como L√≠ngua Estrangeira. O ensino e a forma√ß√£o em PLE ocupam um entre-lugar, advindo da estranha-familiar rela√ß√£o com a l√≠ngua portuguesa.

title: Compreens√£o de textos no AVC e baixa escolaridade
abstract: A pesquisa comparou a compreens√£o de seis narrativas (lidas e ouvidas) por 18 indiv√≠duos com AVC no hemisf√©rio esquerdo a 10 controles, com baixa escolaridade, verificando o desempenho nos n√≠veis micro- e macroestruturais textuais atrav√©s de recontos e perguntas de compreens√£o.

title: O mal-entendido em tweets
abstract: Nosso trabalho consiste em descrever o monitoramento do mal-entendido em tweets, destacando sua din√¢mica organizacional, fatores que o desencadeiam, a√ß√µes de den√∫ncia e reparo e, ainda, o trabalho de face. Recorremos aos estudos da An√°lise da Conversa e Lingu√≠stica Interacional.

title: O papel da gama tonal na caracteriza√ß√£o dialetal
abstract: A an√°lise da gama tonal apontou valores m√≠nimos id√™nticos em ambos os tipos fr√°sicos, tanto para o Norte quanto para o Sul. Todavia os valores m√°ximos alcan√ßados pela F0 das senten√ßas sulistas s√£o sempre superiores √†queles atingidos pelas nortistas em perguntas e asser√ß√µes.

title: Processing linguistic variation
abstract: This paper explores the effects between implicit and explicit knowledge about linguistic variation. An experimental study shows that stigmatized phonological variants present differences in the awareness task while in unawareness task the pattern is similar to casual speech.

title: Aspectos cognitivos e avalia√ß√£o de linguagem
abstract: Nesta confer√™ncia apresentarei alguns dos resultados expostos em Silva (2018), em que investiguei se e quanto, caracter√≠sticas relacionadas ao estilo, trajet√≥ria de vida e sa√∫de de diferentes participantes, poderia influenciar no seu desempenho em uma avalia√ß√£o de conversas.

title: Children use prosody for sentence disambiguation
abstract: Can Brazilian children use prosody to constrain their interpretation of sentences? In our study, 3-4-yos correctly interpreted sentences such as "The tiger hits! The duck too", which, without prosody, are ambiguous with transitive sentences such as "The tiger hits the duck too".

title: Varia√ß√£o lingu√≠stica na leitura em voz alta
abstract: Varia√ß√£o lingu√≠stica ocorre em contexto de leitura em voz alta? Essa exposi√ß√£o sistematiza resultados de estudos que investigaram a transposi√ß√£o de tra√ßos vari√°veis da fala para a leitura em voz alta e aponta as principais contribui√ß√µes ao ensino de leitura e √† sociolingu√≠stica.

title: Texto, ensino e historiografia da lingu√≠stica

title: Referencia√ß√£o e argumenta√ß√£o pol√™mica no twitter
abstract: Esta pesquisa tem o objetivo de analisar a (re)constru√ß√£o dos processos referenciais no twitter e o modo como eles interferem na instaura√ß√£o do discurso pol√™mico. Para isso, toma-se como pressupostos te√≥ricos os estudos da Lingu√≠stica Textual e da Argumenta√ß√£o no Discurso.

abstract: O tecnodiscurso traz particularidades que precisam ser levadas em considera√ß√£o por linguistas. Este trabalho, assumindo uma abordagem p√≥s-dualista e ecol√≥gica (PAVEAU, 2017), reflete sobre o uso de tecnotextos como corpus nos estudos em Lingu√≠stica Textual.

title: Feedback as the main mechanism of L2 processing
abstract: In speech interaction, speakers integrate the bottom-up acoustic signal with top-down lexical knowledge and context fastly. The lexical feedback mechanism may be the main way of speech comprehension by bilinguals since the acoustic input is decoded by a L1 and L2 mixed system.

title: Valida√ß√£o de um teste de compreens√£o de prov√©rbios
abstract: Neste trabalho, apontamos evid√™ncias de validade de uma tarefa de compreens√£o de prov√©rbios. Como resultado desse processo, verificamos que a habilidade de compreens√£o de prov√©rbios se desenvolve gradualmente, com efeito significativo da idade e da escolaridade dos participantes.

title: Multimodal perception of Brazilian Portuguese
abstract: This paper presents a multimodal analysis of the intonation of assertions, echo-questions, wh-exclamations, and wh-questions in Brazilian Portuguese. We explore the influence of the visual channel in the perception of the prosody of these four utterance types.

title: Matrix Language in the Code-Switching in Children
abstract: This work focuses on the Matrix Language (ML) of intra-clause Code-Switching in children and adults in bilingual data Venetian/Spanish in Puebla, Mexico. The purpose is the identification of the ML in all clauses in a family interaction based on the Matrix Language Frame model.

title: Efficient coding: Passive and dative alternations
abstract: What unites passive and dative alternations is the effect of unusual associations of role rank (A >P, R > T) and referential prominence (e.g. definite > indefinite). Unusual associations may lead to special coding for reasons of efficiency, as in differential object marking.

title: Measuring the lexical distance between dialects
abstract: Employing CL on the Dialects of Arabic and ‚ÄéMeasuring the Lexical Distance between them compared to MSA. Testing the functionality of Swadesh list on the main and frequently used dialects, to find the link and the bond of these dialects to the MSA and even ‚Äébetween each of them‚Äé

title: How priming in bilinguals leads to language change
abstract: Does adjective-noun order change through cross-language priming (bilinguals repeat order in L1 after using it in L1‚Äô)? We study priming in ms (experiment w/ 90 Romani-Romanian bilinguals) & effects throughout centuries (119 Romani speakers from various countries in RMS database)

title: Bilingual mixed NPs: speech data vs. models
abstract: In bilingual NPs, what decides the determiner's language? Abstract features or Matrix language? Neither, by bilingual community norms. In spontaneous bidirectional mixing data, preferred are lone nouns. The determiner is thus that of the surrounding language, whatever it may be.

title: Pragmatic and discursive mechanisms in headlines
abstract: The pragmatic analysis of 1030 headlines in research project websites shows that promotional strategies outnumber communicative and interactional ones to foster collective impact. Discursively, they tend to display non-verbal structures, self-references, and engaging devices.

title: What counts as alternating passive constructions?
abstract: An overview of an on-going project for mapping variants used in Brazilian Portuguese to conceptualize passive propositions in academic and journalistic texts, adopting a socioconstructionist view of multivariate usage-based language knowledge, allostruction and (meta)construction

title: Gricean Secrets
abstract: Fox (2014) argues that Griceans cannot generate scalar implicatures observed in some adversarial contexts. I reply by showing that, contra Fox, Griceans can derive these implicatures. Therefore, Fox‚Äôs argument fails to undermine the Gricean approach to scalar implicatures.

title: Cats of Twitter
abstract: Cats of Twitter (aka people behind the screens talking as a cat, as if they were a cat) as a community of practice? YES! As they impersonate cats as ambivalent animals, Twitter users gather around a style + lead sociolinguistic change & the dissemination of norms of use.

title: National language literacy lessons in The Gambia
abstract: The Gambia‚Äôs 2015 biliteracy programme prescribes that from grade 1 to 3 primary school children should receive an equal number of literacy lessons in one of The Gambia‚Äôs seven national languages and English. Find out what 12 Gambian educators had to say about it in interviews.

title: Ideologies in a university linguistic landscape
abstract: This linguistic landscape study examines the language on signs in University College Dublin, Ireland in relation to university policies and value statements. The results show that multilingualism on campus signage does not support the overt global orientation of the institution

title: The Decline of V2 in the History of English

title: Frame Semantics & Multimodal Machine Translation

title: A Classless Analysis of Italian Nouns
abstract: Italian has stems of root+theme vowel with many irregular pairings. Decompositional analyses need problematic class features. Class is an unnecessary diacritic, and is replaceable with underlying root shapes. This leads to a more streamlined derivational architecture.
